Award.AwardTitle: Optimization of Carbon Nanotube Based Chemical Sensors Through Micro-Raman Enabled Defect Analysis

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: The objective of this research is to develop highly efficient carbon nanotube (CNT) based chemical sensors through in-situ identification and manipulation of defects in the CNT conduction channel. These defects play a central role in CNT electrochemical sensitivity but there has been no rigorous study of how specific defect types and/or distributions affect actual CNT-based devices. The approach is based on a unique and highly integrated process involving micro-Raman spectroscopy, electron microscopy, numeric modeling and microenvironment electrical characterization.

This research tackles one of the principle roadblocks to the enormous potential of CNT-based chemical sensors. The intellectual merit includes: (1) the development and evaluation of low-cost CNT-based chemical sensors with improved analyte sensitivity, efficiency and selectivity; and (2) the advancement of nanometrology by combining both fundamental material and device characterization techniques with numerical modeling. This comprehensive three-pronged approach has never been employed to systematically examine CNT conduction channels in actual working devices. The proposed research will provide an in-depth understanding of how these defects affect the performance of working nanodevices and enable a new methodology for characterizing nanoelectronics.

The various research activities of this project will involve minority undergraduate students and girls from local K-12 schools through NSF-sponsored LSAMP/REU and Oregon Saturday Academy programs to enable students to learn research skills and to join a competitive workforce in the future. The research findings will be disseminated broadly through journal publications, conference presentations, seminars, and the PIs? websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to utilize Raman spectroscopy to quantify and locate defects in individual carbon nanotube field-effect transistors (CNT-FETs) and to correlate these defects to their electron transport properties in trace-gas environments. This study enabled a more detailed understanding of the role of defects in the adsorption process, the effect of adsorbates on CNT band structure, and how to tailor CNT-FETs to be optimized for the chemFET gas-sensor application. The major accomplishments are summarized below:

 

1. Fabrication of chemFETs

In the duration of this project, we have fabricated more than 1000 CNT-FETs by further refining the CNT growth and device fabrication methods to improve CNT-FET yield and produce a sufficiently large population of devices. In addition, a direct-write lithography system was integrated into our Raman spectrometer to facilitate future device fabrication during our chemFET optimization phase.

 

2. Electrical screening to identify testable devices

Automated electrical CNT-FET testing was carried out and a new automated Raman scanning routine was also developed and implemented to supplement these measurements.

 

3. Electron microscopy of selected devices

Electron microscopy characterization was continuously carried out in coordination with Raman spectroscopy to identify suitable devices for electrical characterization.

 

4. Micro-Raman spectroscopy to locate & identify defects

We have carried out an intensive mapping initiative to provide a large statistical analysis of chemFET defects. In order to complete this portion of the project, specialized analytical software was also developed.

 

5. Development of numeric model to predict defect effect

Based upon the insights gained from graphene computational models and our ability to reproduce the existing computations presented in CNT-related literature, we have complete confidence in our computational models towards comprehensive studies.

 

6. ChemFET testing in MEPS system

This project has pioneered photostimulated transport and cryogenic adsorption/desorption investigation enabled by our development of a micro-environmental probe station (MEPS), which allows us to combine these insights with the Raman spectroscopic characterizations, electronic characterizations and ultimately achieves the final goal.

 

7. Training future workforce

This project has directly facilitated the professional growth of a number of students under the supervision of the PI and graduate students: Walter Hudson, Daniel Hedinger, Alex Jacobson, Spencer Krum, Robin Ekeya, Tracie Tran, Rachel Osmundsen, Brittany Timonen, Alex Stendahl, Elizabeth Allan-Cole.

 

These students have worked towards instrumentation and software development (polarization-dependent Raman spectroscopy, direct-write lithography, chemical vapor deposition reactors, and probe stations) and have contributed towards synthesis, fabrication, and measurements, which were crucial towards this project. These techniques, Raman spectroscopy, electron and optical microscopy, electron transport, wet chemistry, chemical vapor deposition, and lithography, are all critical techniques for the broader field of material science which will be a vital contribution to their careers.
